hedline.hl1: Officer Convicted in Slaying Of Man in Brooklyn Shootout

block.p: A New York City police officer who fatally shot a man in an early-morning dispute was found guilty yesterday of second-degree manslaughter.

A New York City police officer who fatally shot a man in an early-morning dispute was found guilty yesterday of second-degree manslaughter.

The officer, Noel Barnett, 31 years old, who was off duty at the time of the shooting, testified at a nonjury trial before Justice Edward Rappaport of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn that he was acting in self-defense after the victim, Jack Johnson, 25, a city correction officer, shot at him last June.

Officer Barnett, who has been in the Police Department since 1980, faces a possible five to 15 years in prison when he is sentenced on June 19. He was suspended from the force without pay after the conviction and faces a department trial.
